data.text: Join us on Tuesday, October 27 at 8.00 am (EDT) for a virtual panel “Coping with COVID-19: Challenges and Policy Priorities for the MENA Region and the Global Economy”, following the launch of the IMF’s 2020-2021 Regional Economic Outlook for the region.  https://t.co/X5StpP2aPe

The near-universal membership of the IMF can help ensure that the digital revolution in finance benefits people in all countries. Read @KGeorgieva and Tobias Adrian's blog on #CrossBorderPayments here: https://t.co/sENaMVIIxn #IMFBlog https://t.co/k63jS6RiVK

Countries in sub-Saharan Africa took swift action to protect their people from the worst of the crisis but lockdown measures came at high costs. The response has widened an already sizeable external financing gap. https://t.co/C7xJcEAcDT #IMFBlog https://t.co/vroATVACYK

The latest Regional Economic Outlook for Sub-Saharan Africa projects economic activity in the region to decline by 3.0% in 2020 and recover by 3.1% in 2021. Read more here: https://t.co/k3z9QTHIA8 #IMFAfrica https://t.co/skYZHjWa08

IMF’s Zhang at 2nd Bund Summit: Global recovery will be long, uneven, and uncertain. Policymakers must look beyond the immediate recovery and implement longer-term measures that generate more inclusive, smarter, and greener growth. https://t.co/SSjillDU4d https://t.co/FATdMmjkgG

The significant improvement in market sentiment has helped maintain the flow of credit, but we are concerned about the disconnect between financial markets and the uncertain evolution of the economy. https://t.co/31p9mkEGE9 #IMFBlog https://t.co/FuTuSrfSPH

If you lift women economically and put money in a woman’s hands, she spends it on family and everybody else. REWATCH @melindagates and @KGeorgieva's conversation during the #IMFMeetings https://t.co/0jZJ5bk2Ob #inclusiverecovery https://t.co/CiF4VcrG8R

Our latest #GFSR research shows that massive monetary and fiscal support across the globe have helped contain financial stability risks for now, despite the biggest recession since the Great Depression. https://t.co/T24KOjYZu2 https://t.co/tTacIrBBtG
REPLAY: Press briefing on the latest economic outlook for the Caribbean and Americas. #IMFAmericas https://t.co/oWf5drzIgB

In the latest issue of the World Economic Outlook, IMF Chief Economist Gita Gopinath says the recession will continue in 2020 with global growth projected at -4.4% and a partial rebound to 5.2% growth in 2021. Read the #WEO report. https://t.co/XMCO1e58iW https://t.co/IOPz30Aih1

The latest Regional Economic Outlook for Sub-Saharan Africa projects economic activity in the region to decline by 3.0% in 2020 and recover by 3.1% in 2021. Read more here: https://t.co/Zuwp6mAXLt #IMFAfrica https://t.co/qDNLoIit3S

Our new #FiscalMonitor shows that an increase in public investment by 1% of GDP can create up to 33 million jobs in the advanced and emerging economies. Learn more https://t.co/4yV6zroLRJ https://t.co/nzPZ5xtE0X

Fiscal policy needs a strategy to adapt to the unprecedented challenge from COVID-19, tailored to the phase of the pandemic. Our new #FiscalMonitor shares the details. https://t.co/7VP5Da6T5O #IMFBlog https://t.co/NjwwbsyRyb

Countries in sub-Saharan Africa took swift action to protect their people from the worst of the crisis but lockdown measures came at high costs. The response has widened an already sizeable external financing gap. https://t.co/C7xJcEAcDT #IMFBlog https://t.co/LYC9D6zaE0

COVID-19 has exacerbated debt vulnerabilities in sub-Saharan Africa. While debt relief provided by the IMF and G20 will ease some of the burden, more financing is needed. More here: https://t.co/k3z9QTHIA8 #IMFAfrica https://t.co/0KF2RfOqdI

.@KGeorgieva : Unless we zero in on the most vulnerable: women, youth, and low-skilled workers, we will see a tremendous loss in hard-won advancements in #gender #equality. #inclusiverecovery

IMF Deputy Managing Director Antoinette Sayeh highlights the importance of strengthening economic institutions and supporting fragile states to enable stronger recovery post #COVID19. Read IMF’s latest capacity development report here: https://t.co/tX2XAN4yRA #IMFCapDev https://t.co/fpIPAuQbXc

In today's edition of the IMF #WeekendRead newsletter, we wrap up the 2020 Annual Meetings with a focus on digital currencies, the impact of lockdowns on jobs, and the launch of regional economic outlook reports, among many other highlights. IMF Werner: Our economic forecast for LatAm & the Caribbean projects a real GDP contraction of 8.1% in 2020, & 3.6% growth in 2021. Most countries will not reach pre-pandemic GDP until 2023, reflecting the long-lasting economic consequences of the crisis.  https://t.co/NA7DPelp8P https://t.co/PyDzNbNl5o

The COVID19 crisis has hit Latin America and the Caribbean harder than other parts of the world, both in human and economic terms, with tourism-dependent Caribbean countries taking a strong economic blow.

The #AsiaPacific region went into this crisis first and many of its economies are emerging from it first as well. What lessons can the world learn from this experience? Read our latest economic outlook here:  https://t.co/WnXgvA1eLP https://t.co/2LZ7rZs0wR

#AsiaPacific is recovering from its worst recession. Our latest Regional Economic Outlook shows that a rebound started in the third quarter, but growth engines are not all firing with the same power across countries, leading to a multispeed recovery.  https://t.co/XqK4NfIESy https://t.co/xGCQ8a4Spt

Our latest study suggests that inequality is deepening in the region and could elevate the risk of social unrest. Governments need economic policies to support the vulnerable groups who are the hardest hit, especially youth and women.  https://t.co/WnXgvA1eLP #IMFAsia https://t.co/PR3CKkIx4p

The #AsiaPacifc region is recovering from its worst recession. We expect growth of 6.9% in 2021 (from -2.2% this year). Scars from the #COVID-19 crisis will be deep: potential output by the middle of the decade could be some 5% lower than before the pandemic. https://t.co/HNAL6W2uqO

We have a special responsibility to tackle these challenges and not let the divides deepen." Watch the interview by  @Silvia_Amaro on the impact of #lockdowns on #women and #youth. https://t.co/CZTb1M1pg7 https://t.co/lZojQKGsQG

.@Joakim_Reiter at the #WEO data presentation with @GitaGopinath: "It is the responsibility of all stakeholders including the private sector to face up to the reality that the consequences of this crisis is a burden not equally shared…

Second, providing parental leave to both men and women so when schools close, both have an equal share in childcare responsibilities. These measures would help make the impact of the crisis less uneven for women and youth." Watch the #WEO presentation: https://t.co/CZTb1M1pg7 https://t.co/M377DfypXz

.@GitaGopinath on what can be done to help #women and #youth during #lockdowns: "First, providing a strong social safety net to protect people who are losing their jobs but also, providing opportunities to the unemployed to transition into new sectors, and...

How much is the burden of the crisis falling on youth? IMF research suggests that #lockdowns tend to have a disproportional effect on those who are economically more vulnerable, such as women and the young. Take a look at the data: https://t.co/ygarIyZ7nG #WEO https://t.co/8O3fji5WIQ

During #lockdowns at the outset of the crisis, the share of people leaving home declined by about 20 percentage points. Yet, the impact on women was larger. Take a look at what’s behind the numbers in our data visualization with @vodafone. #WEO https://t.co/jEz7kMhQRj https://t.co/yfdM6XuIV7
